{{book |title=Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Pearl, and Sir Orfeo | image = Green Knight, Pearl and Sir Orfeo 1975.jpg |author=[[J.R.R. Tolkien]] |editor=[[Christopher Tolkien]] |publisher=[[George Allen and Unwin]] |date=September [[1975]] |format=Hardcover; paperback; deluxe edition |pages=148 |isbn=0048210358 | precededby=[[Bilbo's Last Song (at the Grey Havens)]] {1974) | followedby=[[Letters from Father Christmas]] {1976) }} '''''Sir Gawain and the Green Knight, Pearl, and Sir Orfeo''''' is a book published in [[1975]], edited by [[Christopher Tolkien]]. It collects [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s verse translations of three Middle English texts (all written around 14th century) into Modern English, together with Tolkien's own commentaries: *''[[Sir Gawain and the Green Knight]]'' *''[[Pearl]]'' *''[[Sir Orfeo]]'' On the last page is attached a four-stanza text ''[[Gawain's Leave-taking]]'', which was translated by Tolkien from two other medieval poems. ==Contents== *Preface *Introduction *'''''Sir Gawain and the Green Knight''''' *'''''Pearl''''' *'''''Sir Orfeo''''' *Glossary *Appendix on Verse-forms *''Gawain's Leave-taking'' ==From the publisher== {{Blockquote|This new edition contains the fully-reset text of three medieval English poems, translated by Tolkien for the modern-day reader and containing romance, tragedy, love, sex and honour. It features a beautifully decorated text and includes as a bonus the complete version of Tolkien’s acclaimed lecture on Sir Gawain.
Sir Gawain and the Green Knight and Pearl are two poems by an unknown author written in about 1400. Sir Gawain is a romance, a fairy-tale for adults, full of life and colour; but it is also much more than this, being at the same time a powerful moral tale which examines religious and social values.
Pearl is apparently an elegy on the death of a child, a poem pervaded with a sense of great personal loss: but, like Gawain it is also a sophisticated and moving debate on much less tangible matters.
Sir Orfeo is a slighter romance, belonging to an earlier and different tradition. It was a special favourite of Tolkien’s.
The three translations represent the complete rhyme and alliterative schemes of the originals, and are uniquely accompanied with the complete text of Tolkien’s acclaimed 1953 W.P. Ker Memorial Lecture that he delivered on Sir Gawain.}} ==Publication history and gallery== In [[2020]], a deluxe slipcased edition was published by [[HarperCollins]]. This edition includes: the complete text of Tolkien's [[W.P.
